deliverables/zed/horizon.yaml.message:
@Vishal this needs a MAJOR version bump due to dropping py36/py37 support.
Furthermore, don't forget to ask for a Requirements Freeze Exception on ML (as currently horizon version 22.2.0 is the upper constraint for Zed).

Thanks. updated to the major version. I am just wondering why we need Requirements Freeze Exception. Horizon follows the intermediary releases cycle and this patch just cut a new release to include the latest fixes in the new release. Also, I have done the same thing in the past cycles and never asked for FEE.

Thanks for the update, LGTM.

About the RFE: at R-5 we have the Requirements Freeze date [1]. This is the deadline where things that are constrained in the requirements repository should have been released. (though rel-mgmt process handles exceptions for the next 2-3 weeks).
To tell you the truth i'm not aware of any general exception regarding horizon, but i might missed something.

[1] https://releases.openstack.org/zed/schedule.html#z-rf

I don't think the other patch, https://review.opendev.org/#/q/I4dcaa29ab5eda3fa3272dd5ad1c1f9029ae98b2d is correct either.

--overcloud-ssh-key is respected, it's just not used for what you think it's used for. While I agree it's not entirely clear, I don't think we should be changing any of this in 16/train, unless we're sure of the issue and ramifications.

> The issue is with upgrade to wallaby where there is no mistral environment to get the private key from after the undercloud has been upgraded. Though we could look in /var/lib/mistral for the private key which we don't do atm[4], assuming that the stale config-downloaded directories have the right key is probably not correct(?). 

We could add a step to the undercloud upgrade script to save the private key to a new known location.

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/scripts/undercloud-upgrade-ephemeral-heat.py

> We could add a step to the undercloud upgrade script to save the private key to a new known location.

yeah, we can. But I think we have to get both the keys and then use those for newly scaled-out nodes after overcloud upgrade to 17. We've dropped mistral since ussuri, though it would probably matter less now that we've EOLed both u and v.

> I don't think the other patch, https://review.opendev.org/#/q/I4dcaa29ab5eda3fa3272dd5ad1c1f9029ae98b2d is correct either.

Hmm..let's discuss the "other" patch first. The question is "what key is added to mistral environment ssh_keys and where it's done before the patch"? The reason I put the patch was because, in train using tripleo-admin ssh_user one could not ssh to overcloud nodes and it's broken for sometime. Upgrade uses tripeo-admin as the default user. 

Here my interpretation of the workflow  (SSH variant where the temp private key is used).

- A already authorized user (ex. heat-admin) create a short-term keypair and adds the short-term public key in the remote node[1]
- Then we give mistral the short-term private key to ssh to the node, create the tripleo-admin user and add the public key "in mistral environment" to .ssh/authorized_keys for tripleo-admin[2]
- If there are no ssh_keys in mistral environment then a keypair is generated and stored there[3]

The keypair(private key) generated by mistral is not in the undercloud. How can anyone in the undercloud use it to ssh to remote node with tripleo-admin ssh_user?

Coming back to the current patch, I know that --overcloud-ssh-key is actually meant 
to be used with an "already authorized user", but I expected the same keypair can be used for tripleo-admin too in most cases.

As per storing private keys in mistral, we still do it in[3] when mistral generates them. If storing the "users private_key" in mistral environment is a security concern we can probably remove that.

Let me know if the understanding is incorrect and what other ramifications of these changes. Also, if the patches are incorrect, let's fix this for upgrades as there were several different attempts to fix these issues earlier[4]. 

 
[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/src/branch/stable/train/tripleoclient/workflows/deployment.py#L286-L292
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/src/branch/stable/train/tripleoclient/workflows/deployment.py#L302
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/src/branch/stable/train/tripleo_common/actions/validations.py#L36
[4] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-common/+/676904
    https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/676899

> It's in the mistral environment, and only mistral uses it.

We do have non mistral based upgrade workflow in train[1], that uses tripleo-admin[2] as the default user. But it does get the private key from mistral environment[3].

> Is there a current issue still open that these new patches are meant to address?

The issue is with upgrade to wallaby where there is no mistral environment to get the private key from after the undercloud has been upgraded. Though we could look in /var/lib/mistral for the private key which we don't do atm[4], assuming that the stale config-downloaded directories have the right key is probably not correct(?). 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/stable/train/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_upgrade.py#L202-L208

[2] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/stable/train/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_upgrade.py#L167-L172

[3] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/stable/train/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_upgrade.py#L256

[4] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/stable/wallaby/tripleoclient/utils.py#L1570

I've poprosed https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/857554 and https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/857556. 

I'll revert https://review.opendev.org/#/q/I4dcaa29ab5eda3fa3272dd5ad1c1f9029ae98b2d once we backport these to wallaby.

"The keypair(private key) generated by mistral is not in the undercloud. How can anyone in the undercloud use it to ssh to remote node with tripleo-admin ssh_user?"
  
It's in the mistral environment, and only mistral uses it. There hasn't been a historical need for a user to ssh as tripleo-admin, it's for our automation. If someone really wanted to get the private key, they could download the mistral environment, or get it from under /var/lib/mistral where it's used by config-download.

"Coming back to the current patch, I know that --overcloud-ssh-key is actually meant 
to be used with an "already authorized user", but I expected the same keypair can be used for tripleo-admin too in most cases."

That's never been the case or intended purpose.

you're pointing to a hieradata value, while we're in ansible here. So, no, it will be set by tripleo_httpd_vhost_bind_port variable as passed from the triple-heat-template, taking the actual value of a parameter that wasn't set in the ironic-pxe service, but used in some other ironic related service: IronicIPXEPort

So, in short: operator sets this IronicIPXEPort in parameter_defaults, and that's about it. *before*, it was then translated to the hiera parameter, ironic::pxe::common::http_port. This conversion isn't used anymore.

manifests/profile/base/cinder/volume/nfs.message: Let's use https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-tripleo/+/843579 as the model for ensuring the user has a good experience even if they neglect to provide unique values for the shares config file names. But lets not redesign things in a way that changes the original default value.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: See my comments in similar patch https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/847716

It's fine for the puppet-tripleo patch to provide a default shares config filename in the event that the user neglected to provide on in their multiconfig. However, I do not want to change the design to this extent.

The overall idea of the series of changes is that the Cinder*SharesConfig parameters is not something users should care. The parameters affect name of the config file and does not really affect the behavior of backends.

I understand your point that users are responsible to set parameters properly for each backend so that they get expected behaviors. However ShareConfig does not really affect the functionality and setting unique values are just to avoid ugly internal error. So IMHO this is something we should consider separately.

environments/cinder-netapp-config.yaml.message: This note still applies. It's nice that puppet-tripleo attempts to provide a better experience when the user forgets to assign unique values, but the user is still supposed to be in charge of the values.

It's true that users are responsible to provide values for each backend to get the expected behavior of individual backends, but IMO it's not quite reasonable to require them to avoid failure in Puppet. That is quite internal and is not something users should care IMHO.
I feel this advice is wrong, and is inconsistent with how the multi-config options are designed to work.

But I believe it would still be nice to fix this to allow going through the releases until stable/yoga were the removal of this functionality is properly mentioned in the upgrade notes.
I unearthed https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2009026 while doing bug triage. We should mark this as part of it, or remember to close the story when done.

neutron/common/ovn/hash_ring_manager.py.message: nit: There is a unit test for this method, could update to verify LOG.debug not called.

Even with the change to limit the amount of log spam, this'll still be really nuts when we get a million ovsdb row events and get_node() is called in notify() so we end up doing 2 million calls to get_active_nodes (in wait_startup_before_caching and here). I know python-ovs basically will make a list of all of the events that happen in a single message, and send then loop through them sending all of the notifications, so this happens very very fast.

Just brainstorming, but it seems like maybe it would be beneficial to have the api workers wait for the MaintenanceWorker to spawn before connecting to the ovn dbs, maybe with just the hash ring periodics, then if it's the MaintenanceWorker, add the other periodics. That way we could ensure that touch_nodes is actually called by that worker while we're processing the db notifications.

container-images/kolla/tripleo-ansible-e.message:
The way the ansible-galaxy commands are set up in tcib/tripleo-ansible-ee[1], they'll run if this requirements file exists at all.

Running 'ansible-galaxy role install -r $TRIPLEO_ANSIBLE_REQ' where $TRIPLEO_ANSIBLE_REQ is a file that doesn't actually contain any role definitions returns error code 1 with this output:
> ERROR! No requirements found in file 'requirements.yaml'
Which I believe would break builds of the tripleo-ansible-ee container if this were to merge as is.

I can think of two ways to avoid that:
1) Delete this file entirely, so that the "if [ -f "$TRIPLEO_ANSIBLE_REQ" ]" checks[1] don't pass and ansible-galaxy never runs (unless the user created it for the express purpose of installing stuff via ansible-galaxy)
2) Keep the file and alter those checks to further verify whether any roles/collections are actually defined in it.


[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/src/commit/54a6bac5d557aa84c21986e96db0e0911792fe1b/container-images/tcib/tripleo-ansible-ee/tripleo-ansible-ee.yaml#L18

```
roles: []
```

This is anyway very inefficient whatever we do.

and provide valuable versioning comments and updates.  So, a deployer can know what is in the driver and what's been fixed/added over time. Two issues here:

(1) Having these module-level vars is a testing anti-pattern, because if they're modified in one test, the modification carries over to other tests, and can cause them to fail if they're not run in a particular order.

(2) There are functions in cinder.tests.unit that will generate test objects for most of these ... that way you would be using an actual cinder object instead of a generic mock.  (Generic mocks don't complain if you call a non-existent method on them, for example, which could allow tests to pass when they shouldn't.)


Not holding the patch up over these (since you aren't introducing either issue, they're already here), but you should review the tests and think about refactoring.

Just want to verify that this is what you want.  Is there no backend metadata that should be kept?  See line 911, where cinder-specific metadata is set.  Do we want to clear only those fields?  (Same thing for unmanage snapshots.)
I had the same doubt but thought they are only using metadata for OpenStack related purpose and it has no usage in their backend but let's see what Alexander says.

Hello Brian,

Thank you very much for the review!

>> Just want to verify that this is what you want.
>> Is there no backend metadata that should be kept? 
>> See line 911, where cinder-specific metadata is set.  
>> Do we want to clear only those fields? (Same thing for unmanage snapshots.)

Yes of course. The Infinidat driver stores a metadata on the storage side (as metadata for an Infinidat volume) and this metadata can be internally used on the Infinidat storage side for management and analytics. For example, to distinguish Cinder-managed volumes from other volumes (the Infinidat storage system uses a flat namespace). And when we "export" a volume from Cinder management, we must clear all existing metadata so that it can be seen on the storage side that this volume no longer belongs to any service or application.

Thank you!

Yes I was already aware of this code and even revisited it this morning before submitting the review.

 > i woudl try to avoid assuming the use of libvirt/kvm here.

controllerconfig/controllerconfig/upgrad.message: shouldn't this migration taken at "migrate" action? The controller-1 would become active controller after "migrate" but well before "activate".

On top of what Rei says, it's ok not having the openldap certificate during upgrade, we don't use any ldap users during upgrade. We only need to ensure after upgrade, the openldap cert and key are in file system so that ldap user and login to the system (both system controller and subcloud). So I think it doesn't matter at what stage of upgrade the openldap cert is created.

BTW, we have more USs to address upgrade wrt the newly introduced secure openldap feature. This is just one of them.

The certificate itself as a cert-manager certificate is valid, but we need the updated cert-mon and sysinv ldap plugin changes in place as well in order to properly install the certificate to the filesystem in /etc/ldap/certs; we need the new code in 22.12 for that to work.

I don't think patching is necessary, since we are introducing these ldap related changes as part of a new feature. 

Subclouds particularly will be fine, since the role bootstrap/install-platform-certificates invoked by the playbook will only install the certificate in a dc system controller. Also in ldap.py the plugin code does not use the certificate in subclouds.
Thanks Rei and Andy for the explanation.

I need to run this script to create the openldap certificate in a moment where the new load is in the active controller already. 

The creation of the openldap certificate will trigger the install action by cert-mon and ldap plugin which depend on new code introduced in 22.12.

So it means the cert is not valid until upgrade activate?
It sounds to me that a clean fix will be 
1. patch 22.06, so 22.06 active controller can complete installing the certificate, or
2. trigger the installation from outside of cert-mon on controller-1 after data migrate completes.
currently the system will run without the proper certificate until upgrade activate. Do we know all the possible impact of not having the proper certificate, especially on a subcloud upgrade?

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/puppet/ldap..message: When upgrade is in one of the above states, has the new upgrade scripts finished already (ie, openldap cert is truely ready)? The reason I'm asking is that, the upgrade scripts will run at activate stage, not sure it's finished at this point.

I'm tweaking this yet Andy.

I think it will actually end up being:

        activating_statuses = [
            constants.UPGRADE_ACTIVATING,
            constants.UPGRADE_ACTIVATING_HOSTS,
            constants.UPGRADE_ACTIVATION_COMPLETE,
        ]
        
The certificate is created during the activating status, but the installation by puppet and cert-mon may happen during the next two stages.

zuul/model.py.message: The toDict() method seems to be also used by the freeze-job API. Just wondering if we want to include the alternatives there.
Because it's flattened when frozen, there should never be any alternatives, so it will be unused code, but it does seem like we should include it for correctness.  I'll add that in the next PS.
Yes that's correct, and the tests now verify that alternatives are included.
How about the "job" API endpoint? This one is not using the FrozenJob but the Job config object. I would expect that this configuration is visible to users in some way there.
`self.alternatives` is a list and not a dict
Would it make sense to make _flattenAlternatives a static class method to make the argument for recursion a little less odd? Minor nit.
I don't really see a difference either way.
Do we need an extra method for this?
It's an API.  Several model objects have this method.  It's used in configloader.  It may do other things in the future.
It mostly just reads oddly to pass in self when self is already implicitly passed. But it makes sense when you read the method and find that it is recursive.

Since we write both the nodeset_alternatives and nodeset in the serialize case that means we can override the singleton nodeset definition above if not all components are at api version 9.

This isn't a major issue, but it does point out a behavior expectation question. Should we continue to act as v8 until everything is v9 or are we ok to act like v9 here? I'm concerend that reasoning through all the corner cases for v8 mixed with v9 here may be difficult and we're better off just proceeding with v8 instead for consistency with all nodes.

All that to say maybe this block from 2246-2247 needs to be in an else case for the block at 2240-2244? Then do the data conversion in 2248-2250 if necessary.
That is a good point. I agree it is unlikely for people to immediately start using the feature before we've transitioned completely to the new api in a cluster.

The current code does mean that once sufficient numbers of nodes are API-9-capable, they will immediately start obeying the alternatives even before all components are updated.  But any <9 components will still work as before.

Given that we're talking about a pretty long process with frozen jobs, etc, it doesn't seem *wrong*, per se, to start obeying alternatives for jobs that have already been frozen if they were configured that way.

But I think the thing that makes this more-or-less moot is that it seems *very* unlikely for the system to already have nodeset alternatives configured during the upgrade process since it's a new config syntax.  So this shouldn't really matter in practice.

I'm not sure I understand the len(alts[0]) check here. We perform the same action in this block as the elif below. Can they be combined?

In particular if alts[0] is a str or a dict len(alts[0]) will report non zero value for non empty vars. And if it is a NodeSet object then len() won't apply to it?

Re the first thing: the two blocks assign to different dictionary keys (nodeset vs nodeset_alternatives), so the actions aren't quite the same (not sure if that's what you meant or not).

Re the second: flattenNodesetAlternatives will always return a list of Nodeset objects, so alts[0] if it exists is always a nodeset.  Nodeset implements __len__ which indicates how many nodes it has.  So these lines say:

If there is only one nodeset and it has nodes, set the 'nodeset' attribute to that nodeset.
If there is more than one nodeset, set the 'nodeset_alternatives' attribute to the list.
If there are no nodesets or the single nodeset is the empty nodeset, set no attributes.

This retains the old behavior where the nodeset attribute is not included on jobs that don't specify it.

Got it, so this is purely to support human visible representation. I was worried there was some mismatch in attributes that would create functional problems. But I can see where we freeze the job we don't use the toDict representation we build a new direct representation for the frozen state. So toDict here must be going straight out to API responses.

Thanks, I think the bit I was missing is that nodeset may not be set if it is empty. Reading the old code it seems that it wasn't set if there was no nodeset in the layout. Which is maybe equivalent here.

That said, now I'm wondering why we allow FrozenJob and Job to differ when it comes to having a nodeset or nodeset_alteratives attribute. Should we try and use nodeset_alternatives everywhere for consistency? Do we not do that because the name in the yaml is still nodeset ? And if so is it safe to sometimes have a nodeset_alternatives here instead? We don't set a nodeset_alternatives below at line 2570.

A job (now, just as before) has a single nodeset.  That nodeset used to be a single, um, set of nodes.  But now it is actually an even more complex data structure which may be a set of nodes, or it may be a tree of sets of nodes.  Regardless, when we're talking about a Job representing what the user specified in the config, it merely has a nodeset.

Given that, we could just stop there and never have anything called "nodeset_alternatives" on the Job.

However, when we think about what users want to see in the web UI, when you're looking at a Job in the web UI, you're looking at a visual representation of the definition.  To date, if a user specified a nodeset by name on a job, we would look up the nodeset and show the actual definition of the nodeset.  But now that nodesets are complex tree data structures, if we were to do that we would have quite a challenge to display it on the job page.  It's possible, but I don't relish the idea, and I don't think it's necessary.  I think the most useful thing for the user would be to go ahead and flatten the nodeset alternatives into a list and display them as a sequence.  Basically "this job is defined such that it will use these nodesets in sequence".  To accomodate this use case, we flatten the nodeset in Job.toDict.

A FrozenJob is geared specifically for executing it, so we flatten everything so that we can just run through the list of possible nodesets.  It has no need of a nodeset attribute (except that we use it as a pointer to "the current nodeset within the nodeset alternatives").

I think that it was an oversight of the original (which I approved) to basically encode what the OpenDev mirror was doing in this role.  That has ultimately led to this discussion.

I think that by our self-imposed standards for zuul-jobs this would require flagging and a notification period.  I also agree it's very unlikely to be used anywhere else; but that's a bit beside the point as we've certainly imposed this on all other similar changes, even if they are unlikely to be used elsewhere.  If we want to go this path I'm not opposed, so not -1.

Alternatively, my proposal is that we do something like put each component behind it's own flag for redirection to the local mirror -- https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul-jobs/+/857988

This change keeps the current default ans we could commit it immediately without any backwards compatibility concerns.  We could then commit a change to the opendev base jobs to enable extras-common via this method -- satisfying this requirement.

I think I would probably leave it there, but we could also *disable* everything (i.e. have everything use the metalink by default, unless you opt-in) via the usual deprecation case.  I would suggest though that we just leave it as is, but as we add new distros in the future, make sure we start with everything disabled and opt-in to avoid us ever having to change something here in an incompatible way.
